thread.title: Savings bond rates keep edging up as Charter improves its deals
thread.title_full: Savings bond rates keep edging up as Charter improves its deals

author: Sophie Christie
title: Savings bond rates keep edging up as Charter improves its deals
text:
Comments 
Charter Savings, the "challenger" bank that launched in March, has improved its fixed-rate bond range, pushing all but one to the top of the best buy tables. 
The new versions of its one, two, three, four and five year bonds can be opened with a minimum of £1,000 online. The funds cannot be accessed for the duration of the term. 
The one-year bond pays 2.06pc (up from 2pc), the two-year bond pays 2.25pc (up from 2.16pc), the three-year bond pays 2.65pc (up from 2.25pc), the four-year bond pays 2.75pc (up from 2.35pc) and the five-year bond pays 3.05pc (up from 2.5pc). 
• Full details: Charter Savings Bank fixed-rate bonds VERDICT 
Charter Savings Bank has been one of the most proactive of the "challenger" banks since its launch earlier this year. 
Each of the five new rates on offer are market leading, apart from the two-year bond, which sits just behind Punjab National Bank (paying 2.3pc) and Vanquis Bank (paying 2.26pc). 
The one-year bond, paying 2.06pc, edges just above United Trust Bank's recently launched account paying 2.05pc, the first one-year fix to breach the 2pc level in almost a year. 
Putting £15,000 into Charter's one-year bond would accrue interest of £309 , before tax. The two-year bond would earn £338 , the three-year bond would earn £398 , the four-year bond would accrue interest of £413 and the five-year bond would earn interest of £458 . All amounts are before tax. 
All-in-all, the improvements made by Charter Savings Bank is great news for savers, as competition in the market steadily pushes rates up. 
The fixed-rate bond sector has seen more competition in recent weeks than other areas of the savings market, with several rate improvements and best buy accounts launched last month.
